descript.abstract: Mineral Resources, 1996 is a point theme representing mineral deposits worldwide.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf:
Mineral resources are natural substances that are used to produce power and raw materials for economic needs. Mineral resources are irregularly distributed and nonrenewable (exhaustible). In other words, mineral resources can be restocked only through exploration and the development of new deposits. Deposits are subject to different natural, technological, and economic conditions of development and exploitation.
The definition of mineral resources is economic. It does not depend directly on the rock content of a useful substance.
Scientific and technological progress allows new deposits to be exploited that have a lower content of useful substances, higher content of impurities, or worse ore occurrence. New minerals begin to be mined as well. Hence, the array of mineral resources that are used by humans is constantly expanding.

procstep.procdesc:
The maps of mineral resources were compiled by the specialists of the Russian Research Institute of Geology of Foreign Countries. They reflect the contemporary state of mineral resources of the continents. The database contains information about significant deposits and ores of various minerals, which form the basis of the industrial potential of various countries.
Minerals are classified into groups, such as ferrous, nonferrous, rare, precious and radioactive metals, nonmetalliferous minerals, precious and industrial stones, and fuels. Some kinds of minerals that are similar in genetic features, chemical composition, or use are combined (e.g., gas and gas condensate, quartz and quartzite, apatite and phosphorite, and common and rock salts). More than 90 minerals are listed.
All deposits are characterized by genetic type, major type or group of minerals, size, and type or types of minerals. Traditionally, genetic types are not given for oil and gas fields. The classification of genetic types of deposits is based on V. I. Smirnov's classification (1982).
Each deposit (ore area) is given a three-term number. The first two terms mark a trapezium formed by the meridians and parallels of a particular map sheet. The third term is an identification number for the deposit within the trapezium.
All presently known mineral deposits of significant size are accounted for. Deposits that have been discovered in recent years but have not been developed or proven are also shown. However, deposits that are exhausted or close to it and are no longer commercially significant have been omitted. Thus, the maps indicate the actual state of mineral resources of countries and continents. Deposits on different continents were classified in the same way. This makes it possible to compare the industrial potential of countries and continents.
The database and maps were compiled from original cartographic materials as well as from data published for many years in journals, reference books, and monographs.
